Description: THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY COMMUNITY NEEDS AND USES OF FIRE WEATHER AND SMOKE INFORMATION TO INFORM THE RESPONSE TO WILDFIRES AND EVACUATION DECISIONS. THE RESEARCH WILL EXPAND ON EXISTING THEORIES AND APPROACHES TO EXPLORE PERCEPTIONS OF WILDFIRE BEHAVIOR AMONG INDIVIDUALS, AND SMOKE PREDICTIONS FOR COMMUNITIES OCCUPYING WILDFIRE-PRONE LANDSCAPES IN THE UNITED STATES. THE FOCUS WILL BE ON REGIONS WITH RECENT INCIDENCES OF EXTREME FIRE WEATHER-PRODUCING OR LARGE WILDFIRE EVENTS, WITH STUDY SITES IN CALIFORNIA, OREGON, COLORADO, AND TENNESSEE. THREE STEPS WILL BE UTILIZED DURING THE PROJECT: INTERVIEW CASE STUDIES, SURVEYS, AND AGENT-BASED MODELS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND INFORM RESIDENT WILDFIRE RESPONSE.

THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON ADVANCING DATA ASSIMILATION IN FORECAST MODELS IN ORDER TO IMPROVE WEATHER PREDICTION.  A MULTI-RESOLUTION AND MULTISCALE CAPABILITY WILL BE TESTED ON OPERATIONAL MODELS AND DATA STREAMS.  THIS IS EXPECTED TO RESULT IN BETTER OPERATIONAL FORECASTS, AND INVOLVE EXTENSIVE COLLABORATION WITH VARIOUS RESEARCH AND OPERATIONAL CENTERS.

SEASONAL FORECASTS PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION TO MANY SECTORS OF SOCIETY.  THE UNIFIED FORECAST SYSTEM IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT THE WEATHER ENTERPRISE AS A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM FOR OPERATIONAL WEATHER PREDICTION.  THE NEWLY DEVELOPED SEASONAL FORECAST SYSTEM CONSISTS OF SIX COMPONENTS INCLUDING ATMOSPHERE, OCEAN, LAND, ICE, WAVES AND ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION.  THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO STRENGTHEN AND IMPROVE SEASONAL PREDICTIONS BY IDENTIFYING AND REDUCING MODEL BIASES IN THE OCEAN AND ICE COMPONENTS OF THE SEASONAL FORECAST SYSTEM.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IMPROVE FORECASTS OF WIND GUSTS IN TROPICAL CYCLONES.  VARIOUS SCIENTIFIC TECHNIQUES WILL BE RESEARCHED TO IMPROVE WIND GUST ALGORITHMS.  COLLABORATIONS WITH FORECASTERS AND MODELERS WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE FEEDBACK ON THE UTILITY OF THE WIND GUST METHODS UNDER RESEARCH, AND TO SET THE STAGE FOR TRANSITION OF THIS RESEARCH TO OPERATIONAL USE.

THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TO CONNECT WITH HIGHLY VULNERABLE SOCIETY GROUPS IN NEW YORK CITY, INITIATE COMMUNITY LISTENING THROUGH FOCUS GROUPS AND INTERVIEWS, AND LEARN FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS ABOUT THE CHALLENGES THEY ENCOUNTER IN TAKING PROTECTIVE ACTION IN THE FACE OF WEATHER HAZARDS. RESEARCHERS AIM TO IMPROVE COMMUNICATION BETWEEN COMMUNITY OFFICIALS, RESIDENTS WITHIN HIGHLY VULNERABLE SOCIETY GROUPS, AS WELL AS THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE OFFICES THROUGH WORKSHOPS AND RELATIONSHIP-BUILDING. TWO WORKSHOPS WILL BE HELD WITH FORECASTERS AND COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES FROM HIGHLY VULNERABLE SOCIETY GROUPS TO LEARN ABOUT WARNING DISSEMINATION AND PREPAREDNESS, AND DETERMINE THE MOST APPROPRIATE MESSAGING STRATEGIES AND CHANNELS TO USE TO IMPROVE THE COMMUNICATION OF WEATHER RISKS.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP METRICS TO EVALUATE THE VULNERABILITY OF HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY TO DIFFERENT TYPES OF EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS. THIS WILL HELP THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE TO IDENTIFY THE PRIORITY ZONES AND HOTSPOTS THAT ARE IN URGENT NEED OF ENHANCED COMMUNICATION AND SERVICE IMPROVEMENTS, AND DETECT THE TYPES OF IMPROVEMENTS NEEDED TO IMPROVE RISK COMMUNICATION IN EXTREME WEATHER.  THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO IDENTIFY THE DIVERSE CAUSES OF LIMITED DEMAND FOR AND USE OF NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE PRODUCTS BY PEOPLE SUCH AS DISTRUST, UNDERESTIMATION OF RISK AND VULNERABILITY, CONFUSION, AND LACK OF AWARENESS ABOUT THE AVAILABLE PRODUCTS AND HOW TO USE THEM DUE TO INEFFECTIVE OR UNAVAILABLE COMMUNICATIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE OF SMOKE FORECASTS IN AIR QUALITY MODELS. THIS INFORMATION WILL THEN BE USED TO ASSESS THE NEEDS, VULNERABILITIES AND CHALLENGES OF MIGRANT AND IMMIGRANT WILDLIFE RESPONDERS. RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO DEVELOP METHODS OF COMMUNICATING THE RISKS OF SMOKE EXPOSURE THROUGH SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCE KNOWLEDGE AND PRACTICES.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE REACH AND EFFECTIVENESS OF HEAT RISK EDUCATION AND WARNING MESSAGES IN HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED AND SOCIALLY VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES.  THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION OF A TRAINING CURRICULUM TO CONNECT UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES TO HEAT RISK AND MITIGATION INFORMATION, RESOURCES AND SERVICES.  THE PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED IN COORDINATION WITH THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE AND OTHER PROJECT PARTNERS.

THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO RESEARCH AND DEVELOP IMPROVED HEAT FORECAST MESSAGES IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE.  THE RESEARCH WILL ADDRESS THE COMMUNICATION OF HEAT RISK INFORMATION, WITH A FOCUS ON POPULATIONS WITH GREATER SUSCEPTIBILITY TO HEAT, INCLUDING HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED AND SOCIALLY VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES.
ROUTINE MONITORING OF CLIMATE IN THE STATE OF HAWAI'I: ESTABLISHMENT OF STATE CLIMATE DIVISIONS

THIS PROJECT WILL ADAPT AND DEVELOP THE EXTENDED MODEL EVALUATION TOOLS (METPLUS) VERIFICATION AND DIAGNOSTIC FRAMEWORK TO ADDRESS THE SPECIALIZED NEEDS OF THE OCEANPREDICTION CENTER'S (OPC) MARINE AND CRYOSPHERE FORECASTING. AS THE UNIFIED FORECAST SYSTEM (UFS) EVOLVES INTO A FULLY COUPLED SYSTEM, THE DEVELOPERS AND END-USERS REQUIRE SUFFICIENT TOOLS TO DIAGNOSE AND EVALUATE THE SYSTEM'S STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESS PRIOR TO ACCEPTANCE FOR IMPLEMENTATION. THE ENHANCED MODEL EVALUATION TOOLS (METPLUS) HAS SUBSTANTIAL FUNCTIONALITY TO EVALUATE ASPECTS OF WEATHER OVER LAND, BUT IS MISSING SUPPORT FOR EVALUATION ABOVE AND BELOW THE SURFACE OF OCEANS AND ACROSS THE CRYOSPHERE.  THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE NEXT GENERATION GLOBAL PREDICTION SYSTEM (NGGPS) PROGRAM PRIORITIES (1A  AND B) BY PROVIDING METPLUS-BASED STRATEGIES AND PROCESS-ORIENTED DIAGNOSTICS TO IMPROVE FORECASTING ACROSS SCALES AND APPLICATIONS AND (3G) BY IMPROVING PREDICTION OF ARCTIC CLOUDS, SEA ICE,  OCEANS THROUGH COMMUNITY-SUP
COALESCENCE OF PRECIPITATION FORECASTS TO IMPROVE THE NATIONAL BLEND OF MODELS.

THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE COMPARISON OF EQUIVALENT GLOBAL MOM6 AND HYCOM CONFIGURATIONS PERFORMED IN PRIOR RESEARCH, WHICH SHOWED BROADLY SIMILAR RESULTS FROM THE TWO MODELS, ALLOWING FOR THE POSSIBILITY OF UNIFYING NCEP/EMC'S OCEAN MODELING SUITE FROM WEATHER TO SEASONAL SCALES USING ONE OCEAN MODEL BASED ON MOM6. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON ADVANCING CAPABILITIES WITH MOM6 AS FOLLOWS: I) BUILD, TEST AND VALIDATE 1/12  DEGREE GLOBAL MOM6 AS A FUTURE MESOSCALE OCEAN COMPONENT FOR RTOFS AND EVENTUALLY FOR FUTURE GLOBAL UFS FORECAST SYSTEMS; II) BUILD, TEST AND VALIDATE USE OF 1/12  DEGREE GLOBAL MOM6 WITH RTOFS-DA (NCODA); III) EXPLORE ALTERNATIVE OCEAN DATA ASSIMILATION METHODS FOR THE ABOVE HIGH RESOLUTION MOM6 MODELS USING THE JEDI FRAMEWORK.
